abstracts.cdata!:
The Bepeka Audit Modernization Project
            for Indonesia had the following ratings: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that the overseas training support should
            have followed the strategic assessment as specified in the
            Project Appraisal Document (PAD). The Institutional
            Development Plan (IDP) was developed by a small team of
            consultants without forming a joint State Audit Board
            BPK/consultants task force. The Project needed components
            that supported reform efforts in key external agencies. The
            Project design expected that audit quality of BPK would meet
            international best practices through classroom training by
            Project closure. The IDP needed a change management
            component that targeted the structural issues in BPK. The
            Project tried to secure middle-level staff support at a
            later stage of implementation, but could not effectively
            address the concerns at lower staffing levels about
            inadequate remuneration.
